occurrences.line_text: Their God himselfe, grieu'd at my libertie,
The varlet at his plaint was grieu'd so sore,
And grieu'd, so long to lacke his greedy pray;
That nought him grieu'd to bene from rule deposed downe.
The more it gauld, and grieu'd him night and day,
Which grieu'd her more, that she it could not mend:
Grieu'd to the soule, and groning inwardly,
Whereat much grieu'd against that straunger knight,
There she beheld, that sore her grieu'd to see,
He chauft, he grieu'd, he fretted, and he sigh't,
Could euer find, to grieue the gentlest hart on ground?
And inly grieue, as doth an hidden moth
Did see and grieue at his bold fashion;
And to recouer right for such, as wrong did grieue.
Let not thee grieue dismounted to haue beene,
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
That doubly did him grieue, when so himselfe he found.
They haue him taken captiue, though it grieue him sore.
She gan thereat to fret, and greatly grieue.
She gan a fresh to chafe, and grieue in euery vaine.
Whose nature is to grieue, and grudge at all,
Then would she inly fret, and grieue, and teare
Too greatly grieue at any his vnlucky case.
As if it them should grieue to see his punishment.
Ne once my minds vnmoued quiet grieue,
Did search, sore grieued in her gentle brest,
Then gins her grieued ghost thus to lament and mourne.
Through great impatience of his grieued hed
In that disease of grieued conscience,
Faint, wearie, sore, emboyled, grieued, brent
Whose grieued mindes, which choler did englut,
And grieued at her flight; yet durst he not
Pyrrochles was, and grieued eke entyre;
At last they both agreed, her seeming grieued
Saw all this goodly sport, and grieued sore,
Which when he thought, it grieued him full sore,
Much was he grieued with that gracelesse chaunce,
The which long time his grieued hart did wound,
But grieued was for losse both of her sire,
Now gan he in his grieued minde deuise,
If ought lay hidden in his grieued thought,
Was grieued to restore the pledge, he did possesse.
Restlesse, recomfortlesse, with heart deepe grieued,
Much was he grieued with that haplesse throe,
And grieued sore, that through his fault she had
Doe it disclose, to ease your grieued spright:
But most my Lord is grieued herewithall,
And groning sore from grieued hart entire,
Most enuious man, that grieues at neighbours good,
Tell, me what were they all, whose lacke thee grieues so sore.
Who both in minde, the which most grieueth me,
By which he grew to grieuous malady;
A grieuous gout tormented him full sore,
Did grone full grieuous vnderneath the blow,
Whose grieuous fall, when false Duessa spide,
The things, that grieuous were to do, or beare,
Then of the grieuous smart, which him did wring,
Either for grieuous shame, or for great teene,
And playnd of grieuous outrage, which he red
Of grieuous mischiefes, which a wicked Fay
In ioyous pleasure, then in grieuous paine:
And oftentimes great grones, and grieuous stounds,
And thought so to beguile her grieuous smart;
But so her smart was much more grieuous bred,
And gamesom merth to grieuous dreriment:
His grieuous hurt to garish, that she might,
She gan for me deuise a grieuous punishment.
To do fowle death to dye, or wrap in grieuous woe.
And seem'd more grieuous, then it was before:
And did the rest with grieuous sighes suppresse,
Still as she stood, she heard with grieuous throb
And made it seeme to feele her grieuous paine,
On whom he did inflict most grieuous punishment.
Ne sparing him the more for all his grieuous wound.
Ne yet that gentle Squire, for grieuous paine
Was much more grieuous, then the others blowes:
Red as the Rose, thence gushed grieuously;
Maulgre his host, who grudged grieuously,
That the gore bloud thence gushing grieuously,
Then Griffyth Conan also shall vp reare
Let Grill be Grill, and haue his hoggish mind,
Let Grill be Grill, and haue his hoggish mind,
That had an hog beene late, hight Grille by name,
With chaunge of feare, to see the Lyon looke so grim.
So vp he let him rise, who with grim looke
And ouer them sad Horrour with grim hew,
With hoarie lockes all loose, and visage grim;
Where by the grim floud of Cocytus slow
That Capons courage: yet he looked grim,
For shame, but more for feare of his grim sight,
But he was foule, ill fauoured, and grim,
But lookt on Glauce grim, who woxe afeard
Of two grim lyons, taken from the wood,
Of his grim face, were from approaching scard;
Then brought he forth, with griesly grim aspect,
And sternely him beheld with grim and ghastly looke.
Looking at that same Carle with count'nance grim,
Appearing like the mouth of Orcus griesly grim.
And grimly gnash, threatning reuenge in vaine:
Thereat th'old man did nought but fondly grin,
Her heart for rage did grate, and teeth did grin:
Yet his great yron teeth he still did grind,
And count'naunce sterne vpstanding, gan to grind
He grind, hee bit, he scratcht, he venim threw,
Gnashing his grinded teeth with griesly looke,
And grinning griesly, did against him weld
Threatning with greedy gripe to do him dye
Strongly he stroue out of her greedy gripe
Vpon his throte, did gripe his gorge so fast,
From Lyons clawes to pluck the griped pray.
To reaue by strength the griped gage away:
Vppon his iron coller griped fast,
His corage more, that fro[m] his griping pawes
With griping talaunts armd to greedy fight,
And from her griping pounce the greedy prey doth riue.
And greedily him griping, his auengement stayd.
Those heapes of gold with griple Couetyse,
Ne euer Artegall his griple strong
Tho on his shield he griple hold did lay,
Vpon his sunne-bright shield, and gript it fast withall.
Full many a one for me deepe groand and sigh't,
He deepely sigh't, and groaned inwardly,
Though greeued ghost for vengeance deepe do grone:
Did grone full grieuous vnderneath the blow,
And with great griefe were often heard to grone,
Did grone, as feeble so great load to lift;
And after gaue a grone so deepe and low,
At last his mightie ghost gan deepe to grone,
He lately heard that dying Lady grone,
That speare is him enough to doen a thousand grone.
That made his spright to grone full piteous:
Him grone, as if his hart were peeces made,
And oft to grone with billowes beating from the maine.
That euen for griefe of minde he oft did grone,
Into his gaping throte, that made him grone
Full many a night for her did sigh and grone:
The ground eke groned vnder him for dreed;
And gaue against his mother earth a gronefull sownd.
And sighes, and grones, and euermore does steepe
And oftentimes great grones, and grieuous stounds,
For wondrous great griefe groneth in my spright,
And groneth out his vtmost grudging spright,
Groning full deadly, all with troublous feare,
Then groning deepe, Nor damned Ghost, (quoth he,)
Nor wayld of friends, nor laid on groning beare,
The groning ghosts of many one dismaide
Who groning deepe, thus answerd him againe;
And many Giants left on groning flore;
But they to direfull death their groning ghosts did send.
Yet nathemore forth fled his groning spright,
And groning inly deepe, at last his eyes,
Some litle whispering, and soft groning sound.
And left them groning there vpon the plaine.
Yet inly groning deepe and sighing oft,
Grieu'd to the soule, and groning inwardly,
His groning soule vnto her place of punishment.
There she long groueling, and deepe groning lay,
And groning sore from grieued hart entire,
His ruefull shriekes and gronings, often tore
Then called she a Groome, that forth him led
At which the bushy Teade a groome did light,
Hayle Groome; didst not thou see a bleeding Hind,
And that it was a groome of base degree,
Disguised like that groome of base degree,
Straying alone withouten groome or guide;
But when she parted hence, she left her groome
Thereto he hath a groome of euill guize,
The whiles his guilefull groome was fled away:
But that great yron groome, his gard and gouernment.
That it was Talus, Artegall his groome;
The groome went streight way in, and to his Lord
Which answer when the groome returning, brought
Of this her groome, which he by signes did reede;
Ere long to him a homely groome there came,
It was his owne true groome, the gentle Squire,
Where many Groomes and Squiers readie were,
All sixe strong groomes, but one then other more:
Where groomes awayted her to haue vndrest.
He chaunst to spy a sort of shepheard groomes,
For they themselues were euill groomes, they sayd,
Of two smal grooms, which by their names were hight
And sore annoyed, groping in that griesly night.
He so disseized of his gryping grosse,
When suddeinly a grosse fog ouer spred
So earely ere the grosse Earthes gryesy shade
A shadie groue not far away they spide,
And on the other side a pleasaunt groue
A gloomy groue of mirtle trees did rise,
Within a groue appointed him to meete;
Vnder Slewbloome in shady groue was got,
Into the great Nemoean lions groue.
And closely hid her selfe within the groue.
Seem'd like a groue faire braunched ouer hed:
Vnto a litle groue not farre asyde,
Now mote ye vnderstand that to this groue
The Oceans daughter, in this pleasant groue,
She groueling threw to ground, as hating life and light.
He groueling fell, all gored in his gushing wound.
That groueling to the ground he fell, and fild his place.
And by his side the Goddesse groueling
Doth groueling fall, and with his streaming gore
Downe on the ground his carkas groueling fell;
His face vpon the ground did groueling ly,
Whom when on ground she groueling saw to rowle,
That him vpon the ground he groueling cast;
There she long groueling, and deepe groning lay,
Soone as she saw him on the ground to grouell,
The trembling groues, the Christall running by;
Through many couert groues, and thickets close,
Their groues he feld, their gardins did deface,
And as she lay vpon the durtie ground,
With doubled forces high aboue the ground:
They saw so rudely falling to the ground,
And to the ground his eyes were lowly bent,
Assure your selfe, it fell not all to ground;
His mery oaten pipe, but shund th'vnlucky ground.
The bleeding bough did thrust into the ground,
Then the glad marchant, that does vew from ground
He tombling rudely downe to ground did rush,
And all the while she stood vpon the ground,
So from the ground she fearelesse doth arise,
And with greene braunches strowing all the ground,
And with their horned feet do weare the ground,
The ground eke groned vnder him for dreed;
And prowdly threw to ground, as things of naught;
She fell to ground for sorrowfull regret,
Then downe againe she fell vnto the ground;
Had throwne to ground the vnregarded right:
That all the castle quaked from the ground,
Did fall to ground, and with his heauie sway
His boystrous club, so buried in the ground,
Did fall to ground, depriu'd of natiue might;
That ouer shoes in bloud he waded on the ground.
That to the ground it doubleth him full low
For to haue slaine the man, that on the ground did lye.
Is vndermined from the lowest ground
Her golden cup she cast vnto the ground,
And haue beene thrice hid vnderneath the ground,
Could euer find, to grieue the gentlest hart on ground?
Nothing is sure, that growes on earthly ground:
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
That cursed man, low sitting on the ground,
And threw it to the ground, enraged rife,
This said, adowne he looked to the ground,
And seemd vneath to shake the stedfast ground.
With his long tayle, that horse and man to ground did rush.
Himselfe vp high he lifted from the ground,
Which comming downe to ground, does free it selfe by fight.
That to the ground he is perforce constraynd
Thought with his wings to stye aboue the ground;
And him so strongly stroke, that to the ground him feld.
And freely sprong out of the fruitfull ground,
And daintie deare, which on the ground still fell,
Arayd in antique robes downe to the ground,
Themselues to ground with gratious humblesse bent,
Stretcht on the ground in monstrous large extent,
And kist the ground, whereon his foot was pight;
Fidessa hight the falsest Dame on ground,
And on the ground her selfe prostrating low,
And drew her on the ground, and his sharpe sword,
Lurking in rockes and caues farre vnder ground,
And into a deepe sanguine dide the grassie ground.
She groueling threw to ground, as hating life and light.
In number of the noblest knights on ground,
And ayme at him, fell flat to ground for feare,
For they be two the prowest knights on ground,
Downe fell to ground, and crept into a bush,
Drew by the haire along vpon the ground,
And to the ground her threw: yet n'ould she stent
Then him to ground he cast, and rudely hayld,
Lying on ground, all soild with bloud and mire:
That streight on ground made him full low to lye;
He cast him downe to ground, and all along
Whiles sad Pyrrochles lies on senselesse ground,
No daintie flowre or herbe, that growes on ground,
To shed your liues on ground? wo worth the man,
For still he traueild through wide wastfull ground,
Witnesse the guiltlesse bloud pourd oft on ground,
That deepe descended through the hollow ground,
But all the ground with sculs was scattered,
And that aboue were added to that vnder ground.
So faire and great, that shadowed all the ground,
Where euer that on ground they mote him fynd;
And through his shoulder pierst; wherwith to grou[n]d
That forced him his ground to trauerse wide,
Quite through his braine. He tombling downe on ground,
Whose carcases on ground were horribly prostrate.
And ouerrun to tread them to the ground.
Downe to the ground, a comely personage,
Vnto the ground she cast her modest eye,
Which it suruew'd, as hils doen lower ground;
But not on ground mote like to this be found,
Or who shall lend me wings, with which from ground
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
But to the ground the idle quarrell fell:
Ne scarse his feet on ground were seene to tred;
So greatest and most glorious thing on ground
That groueling to the ground he fell, and fild his place.
But ground he gaue, and lightly leapt areare:
Therefore to ground he would him cast no more,
Both faire and fruitfull, and the ground dispred
His looser garment to the ground did fall,
Strowed with pleasauns, whose faire grassy ground
The cup to ground did violently cast,
There the most daintie Paradise on ground,
Such as attonce might not on liuing ground,
And brought to ground, that neuer wast before;
Ne euer to them yielded foot of ground
For I loue one, the truest one on ground,
Ne did she stay, till three on ground she layd,
To make his wonne, low vnderneath the ground,
And writing strange characters in the ground,
But him perforce vnto the ground it bore:
Their tender feet vpon the stony ground:
They him disarm'd, and spredding on the ground
Vpon the grassie ground, to sleepe a throw;
He is yslaine, which is the ground of all our woe.
Downe on the ground his carkas groueling fell;
And glauncing fell to ground, but him annoyed naught.
Vpon the grassie ground her selfe she layd
And all their glory to the ground downe flings,
That all the ground with precious deaw bedight,
To all faire Ladies, that doe liue on ground.
Lightly vpstarted from the dustie ground,
Sate downe vpon the dusty ground anon,
Sitting beside his mother on the ground;
The quarrey throwes to ground with fell despight,
Fell streight to ground in great astonishment;
The fairest wight on ground, and most of men esteemed.
And fals to ground, to seeke for succour theare,
They rudely droue to ground both man and horse,
And cast himselfe on ground her fast besyde:
The rest he leaues in ground: so takes in hond
That to the ground him meekely made to bowe,
Till Trompart lowly to the ground inclind,
Or buried in the ground from ieopardie,
The old man could not fly, but fell to ground halfe ded.
Now gan the humid vapour shed the ground
Vpon the grassy ground, and by him neare
His face vpon the ground did groueling ly,
Vnworthy wretch to tread vpon the ground,
And spoiles, wherewith he all the ground did strow,
So mightily she smote him, that to ground
And perfect hole, prostrate she fell vnto the ground.
But Britomart vprearing her from ground,
Soone as he heard, himself he reared light from ground.
It is a darksome delue farre vnder ground,
The barren ground was full of wicked weedes,
Till that the rest him seeing lie on ground,
Vpon the ground a while in slomber lay;
Each other horse and man to ground did send;
That all the ground with purple bloud was sprent,
And of those Knights who is most stout on ground,
Those two were foes the fellonest on ground,
Farre vnder ground from tract of liuing went,
Vpon which ground this same great battell grew,
Whom when on ground his brother next beheld,
He falleth nigh to ground, and scarse recouereth flight.
So these two champions to the ground were feld,
So much more sorely to the ground he fell,
That horse and man to ground he quite did beare,
Gainst whom none able was to stand on ground;
That forcibly to ground they both together went.
In hope to take him prisoner, where he stood on ground.
That seemed some blacksmith dwelt in that desert grou[n]d.
That to the ground she smote both horse and man;
And found himselfe on ground in great amazement.
To giue him ground, (so much his force preuayled)
Fell downe to ground, as if the steele had sence,
I ioy to see you lout so low on ground,
Doest conquer greatest conquerors on ground,
Had vnawares her snatched vp from ground.
Ne wist whether aboue she were, or vnder ground.
But for aduantage ground vnto him gaue,
Whom when on ground she groueling saw to rowle,
With that she askt, what ghosts there vnder ground
When he it heard, and how the ground he kist,
Shee sitting by him as on ground he lay,
And kist the ground on which her sole did tread,
He could outlearne, he them from ground did reare:
Vpon the ground in ragged rude attyre,
His head before him tombling on the ground.
That headlesse tyrants tronke he reard from ground,
Sith loue was first the ground of all her griefe,
The roofe vp high was reared from the ground,
And all the ground was strow'd with flowres, as fresh as May.
Ne euer durst her eyes from ground vpreare,
As on the ground, without dismay or dread:
His way still vnder ground, till Thamis he ouertake.
And all things freely grew out of the ground:
Ne any liu'd on ground, that durst withstand
As that it seem'd aboue the ground he went:
That on the ground he layd him like a sencelesse blocke.
He shouldered him from off the higher ground,
That to the ground him quite she ouerthrew,
Soone as she saw him on the ground to grouell,
Ne yet to any other wight on ground,
He started vp, there where on ground he lay,
And on the ground the other fast did stand,
Vppon the ground, which kindled priuily,
They trode, and on the ground their liues did strow,
There dead on ground. What doe ye then deuise
What were those knights, which there on grou[n]d were layd,
At last they haue all ouerthrowne to ground
Is wondrous strong, and hewen farre vnder ground
Which tombling downe vpon the senselesse ground,
And laid his Seneschall low on the ground,
Downe streight to ground fell his astonisht steed,
Then downe to ground fell that deformed Masse,
Whom when he saw on ground, he was full glad,
That on the ground he left full many a corse;
Which of all goodly manners is the ground,
Of all this day on ground, that breathen liuing spright.
But rudely rowld to ground both man and horse,
She deem'd him sure to haue bene dead on ground,
That made him stoupe to ground with meeke humilitie.
That him vpon the ground he groueling cast;
Vnto all errant knights, whereso on ground;
That armed knight, that low on ground he lay;
And there beside him sate vpon the ground
And him vnarm'd, as now he lay on ground,
Vpon the ground, like to an hollow beare;
There left on ground, though in full euill plight,
All in gore bloud there tumbled on the ground,
Vprear'd her from the ground whereon she lay,
Not satisfyde till on the fatall ground
Kissing his hands, and crouching to the ground;
But the bare ground, with hoarie mosse bestrowed,
That wanting breath, him downe to ground he cast;
On the cold ground, maugre himselfe he threw,
Vpon the ground her selfe she fiercely threw,
He reared her vp from the bloudie ground,
Vpon the ground, withouten doubt or dreed,
That in his chauffe he digs the trampled ground,
With those braue armours lying on the ground,
The wretchedst Dame, that liue this day on ground;
Vpon the ground with feeble feete he trode,
Who when on ground they saw their fellow slaine,
He saw the ground all strow'd, and that same Knight
That to the ground he fell in senselesse swone:
Gan him recomfort, and from ground to reare.
His vitall breath, and to the ground him bore,
And falleth downe to ground like senselesse thing,
He lyes (said he) vpon the cold bare ground,
Loosely displayd vpon the grassie ground,
Fell flat to ground, ne word vnto him sayd,
To giue him ground, and shift to euery side,
Traceth his ground, and round about doth beat,
And with his yron club to ground him strooke;
He driuen was to ground in selfe despight;
Came running in, and whilest on ground he lay,
But fell to ground, like to a lumpe of durt;
And many feete fast thumping th'hollow ground,
That to the ground astonished he fell;
For vnderneath the ground their way was made,
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
Did cast to ground, whilest none was them to rew;
Of butchers balefull hand to ground is feld,
Formerly grounded, and fast setteled
Without regard of good, dyes like ill grounded seeds.
But on chast vertue grounded their desire,
Hauing spent all her mastes and her ground-hold,
And plentie, which in all the land did grow;
Great ruth in all the gazers harts did grow,
And all that drunke thereof, did faint and feeble grow.
But griefe (quoth she) does greater grow displaid,
Which troubled once, into huge flames will grow,
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
Saue in that soile, where all good things did grow,
As fresh as flowres in medow greene do grow,
But soone through suff'rance grow to fearefull end;
For when they once to perfect strength do grow,
For not to grow of nought he it coniectured.
Ne suffred them to rise or greater grow,
Next thereunto did grow a goodly tree,
The sacred soile, where all our perils grow;
Emongst the Roses grow some wicked weeds;
Whereof did grow her first engraffed paine;
Still as his wound did gather, and grow hole,
And grow afresh, as they had neuer seene
All things, as they created were, doe grow,
Daily they grow, and daily forth are sent
Sith him he saw still stronger grow through strife,
That much she feard his mind would grow to some excesse.
And euery one gan grow in secret dout
And all dissention, which doth dayly grow
And ouer it his huge great nose did grow,
He let to grow and griesly to concrew,
And his worke lessened, that his loue mote grow:
Into outragious flames vnwares did grow,
Like fruitles seede, of which vntimely death should grow.
And lo the Damzell selfe, whence all did grow,
And wish thee grow in worship and great weale.
Such be our ioyes, which in these forrests grow:
And like in time to further ill to grow,
That made them grow so high t'all honorable hap.
For howsoeuer it may grow mis-shapt,
And prou'd the perfect pleasures, which doe grow
So growen great through arrogant delight
His griesie lockes, long growen, and vnbound,
